reviewText: With the war against boys (Kristina Hoff Summers) we can see how the time is ripe for a divine move toward the feminine. In this movie the Magdaline is clearly more important than Jesus -- after all, she carried the heir -- the blood line. So female to female the blood is passed on and has always been in competition with the Church because of it -- since the Church -- evil and male -- seeks to maintain its dominance. In retrospect this seems interesting in comparison to how Philip Pullman in his triology "His Dark Materials" depcits Eve (Lyra) and there seems to be the further connection with Milton through that.A very nice touch, however, is that the feminine needs protection -- from "Grandfather" to male protector -- Tom Hanks. The feminine remains innocent and mother to us all. A great movie made out of an alright book.It certainly is a great role for Audrey. Great to hear her in English! She was great in Amelie.

reviewText: *****5 Stars: Storyline makes for a riveting read and therefore movie storyline. Ron Howard, Tom Hanks, et al deserve high marks for their work in the movie.Zero Stars: Beneath the great directing and acting is the enthralling Da Vinci Code storyline from Dan Brown's book. The story is a cunning, clever frontal assault on Christianity and Leonardo. Most of Dan Brown's ideas are suspiciously similar to "Holy Blood, Holy Grail" and "The Templar Revelation." Unfortunately, both books are based on myths and legends, not historical facts (from any field of study).Negative stars to Dan Brown for his claims, both spoken and written, that his novel -- from which the movie is based -- is factual and accurate.Point #1. Priory of Scion from 1099...false. Turns out it is a hoax created in 1956 by Pierre Plantard, a pretender to the French throne. Do a wikipedia search on Priory of Sion and find out for yourself.Point #2. Jesus married Mary Magdalene. There is not a single historical document that will back up this claim, although it can be found in fiction.Point #3. Leonardo was a Grand Master of Scion. Refer to point #1Point #4. Leonardo placed symbols in his art. Art historians disagree with the characterizations & supposed "facts" that Dan Brown offers -- again, there is no historical fact to support Mr. Brown's claims.Point #5. Jesus not divine until the 4th century. Again, it is good that Mr. Brown is not trying to make a living as a bibilical scholar or historian as he would be unable to find work. Jesus has consistently been recognized as divine since before his crucifixion, without interruption, up to the present.Point #6. 4 Gospels in New Testament were among 80 - others rejected by the church to protect the "truth." False. The 4 Gospels were without peers in the first century, written by those who knew Jesus Christ.Point #7. The Gnostic Gospels should have more weight than the 4 Gospels (Mathew, Mark, Luke & John). The Gnostic gospels came 150-200 years after Christ and were not likely written by those who the books were named after since those people -- Thomas, Mary Magdelene, Philip, et al -- had all been dead for generations at that point.Even as a work of fiction, Dan Brown's book is troubling. His agenda appears to be to take real people, real places, real pieces of art -- all particularly well known ones -- and methodically infusing distortions from myths, legends, and popular fiction. Mr. Brown's chutzpah in declaring his work as accurate and factual is deeply dishonest and clearly unethical. In fact, I am surprised that it is not illegal.This storyline is not problematic for those who will research the claims and seek truth through experts in art, history and literature. There is plenty available on the internet and via other Da Vinci Code offerings that are very effective in demolishing all -- yes, ALL -- of Dan Brown's claims.But for those that do not have time or desire to get to the bottom of things, they may be misled and Mr. Brown's work has the potential to cause harm to those that accept his version of "facts" and it may impact their faith in institutions, authority, lay organizations, Christianity and religion in general.This movie/storyline has the power to make pessimists out of good people.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed the movie.  I considered it to be the top thriller of 2006.  However, I was disappointed by the book.  The following are a few reasons why the movie is better.  Bear in mind that I may be biased because I watched the movie first.  I had already formed my own idea of the story before reading it.  (Most reviewers who claim that the book is better may suffer from the opposite.)I thought that Book would provide more background information on the founding of Priory of Sion, Opus Dei and Merovigian bloodline.  What I got was superficial discussion on goddess worshipping and overdone sex rituals.  It made me grateful that the Church suppressed all that ages ago.Silas is the most sympathetic character in the movie.  His death is the stuff of tragedy.  I do not feel the same way about him in the book.  His death is practically ruined.  In the book, he and Bishop Aringarosa supposedly sustained heavy gun wounds.  Silas was able to bring Aringarosa to a London hospital, slipped out into a city park and died unnoticed.  Where were the hospital personnel?In contrary of what the book claims, Richard Wagner was not a freemason.  This bit of misinformation undermines my confidence in other esoteric theories expounded by the author.One crytex enhances mystery.  Two is overkill.The main reason that the movie is better than the book is:  The movie implicates the Catholic Church in the main plot of the theft of the Grail.  The book, on the other hand, lays the entire blame on one person, Leigh Teabing, who masterminded murders and extortion.  Bishop acted on his own interest, thus divesting the Church with any responsibilities.  But, what a Bishop of Opus Dei wanted with the Holy Grail?  The book says that he wanted to use it to gain influence with the Pope.  However, a Bishop of Opus Dei can hardly reveal the Grail without undermining his own position.  Considering the history of the Church, the movie plotline is only more appropriate and realistic.  I suspect that was Dan Brown's original intention.  He altered it to pass the censorship in publication, and readapted it in the subsequent movie version.

reviewText: I was pleasently surprised by this movie! I never read the book but after seeing the movie I am considering it. Normally I am not into religious movies but this was not bad. If you are expecting a fast paced, action packed Indiana Jones treasure hunt kind of movie this probably is not the film for you but if you are looking for a suspenseful, dramatic and intellectual movie, give this one a try. It's visually beautiful and has great music. I liked the acting, liked the characters and loved the way it was filmed. I actually heard about the theories the book is based on years ago. As far as the religious meaning behind the movie or the debate of it's fact and fiction, I choose to remain neutral on the topic. I find it in poor taste when people preach about their religious beliefs in a review so I won't do that to anyone reading this. I choose instead to judge this movie on it's artistic value. It was an awesome work of art, had some great twists and turns, kept my attention and I would watch it again though I doubt I would buy it for my collection. This will never be an all-time favorite movie for me but it made me want to read the book and it was certainly worth watching!
